Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Routes to Improve Performance for Membrane Separation of Next Generation Biofuels for Transportation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gasoline is generally blended with plant-derived ethanol, however, ethanol tends to increase the water content in the gasoline and decreases the engine performance. New engineering approaches allow for other fuel products to be produced from plant-derived sources, most notably butanol, which overcomes the aforementioned issues associated with ethanol. However, the butanol product is dilute in water and the water must be removed. Membranes provide a low cost solution to the butanol recovery, but there are performance trade-offs that limit its utility. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will examine a new class of materials that could enable significant improvements in the performance of these membranes. Successful completion of this project would not only advance these membranes, but also accelerate their commercialization through the partnership with Promerus, LLC.

The project will examine an alternative BCP system based on polynorbornenes (PNB); PNB can exhibit a high glass transition temperature (>200 Â°C) and likely large free volume generally absent for high-Tg polymers that could enhance the flux. One critical challenge for BCPs is the development of low cost processing routes that are suitable for high volume manufacturing and yield well-defined microphase-separated structures. This project seeks to determine methodologies to controllable highly reproducible microphase-separated structures and understand their fundamental thermodynamic, dynamic and mechanical properties. Recently, Promerus LLC has developed new, functional group-tolerant polymerization initiators; enabling the synthesis of unique functionalized norbornene BCPs. It is hypothesized that the developed morphology will critically impact the membrane performance with likely trade-offs between flux and selectivity with the size of the hydrophilic/hydrophobic domains. This hypothesis will be tested using a series of copolymers by systematically varying the composition, molecular mass and alkyl side chain to understand how the BCP nanostructure acts to improve performance. The overarching goals of this project are to understand how the structure of the copolymer impacts properties critical to membrane operations and how to control this structure through processing techniques extendable to large-scale manufacturing. Fundamental investigations to elucidate morphology-mechanical property relationships and quantify impact of fouling and defouling on the mechanical, morphological, and separation properties, all as a function of processing conditions will be research. This work will provide fundamental processing-structure-property relationships for BCPs for separations and enable novel material designs for commercialization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project worked in concert with a local industry, Promerus LLC, to understand how to changing how a speciality plastic is made into a thin sheet (membrane) influences its ability to separate butanol, which is a promising renewable fuel in place of ethanol for gasoline, from water. The performance of this plastic in the separation is determined by how fast the butanol comes through the membrane (flux) and the relative amount of butanol to water that passes through the membrane (selectivity). Through changing the solvent used to cast the membrane, the local molecular arrangement of the plastic can be altered that could potentially change these performance characteristics. Unfortunately like an old rubber band, these plastic membranes age to change their characteristics - this aging is a densification of the plastic, which will decrease the flux. This aging is unexpectedly fast for these plastics and we found that this is dependent on how thick the membrane is and the supporting surface. These dependences will challenge the predictive capabilities for the lifetime of the membrane, but we found a simple correlation with the stress that is built into the membrane on casting and its aging rate. One major problem with this membrane material is that transformed from a solid to a liquid when a standard antifoam surfactant (molecule that prevents frothing) is included as woudl be the case for fermentation production of butanol.  We find that the antifoam not only adsorbs on the surface of the solid plastic membrane, but also moves into the bulk through specific interactions between the membrane plastic and the antifoam. This changes the relative hydrophobicity of the membrane and allows the egress of a signficant amount of water into the membrane. This is a serious problem for the membrane performance. As this is a bulk adsorption process, these once promising plastics were found to be unsuitable for the membrane application. Despite this shortcoming, new physical insights were gleaned about aging of these speciality plastics and new methods to understand how very small concentrations of additives can influence the physical properties of membranes. The students involved in this work learned valuable skills associated with advanced measurements and students at the PhD, MS and undergraduate level were involved. This project provided the first research experience for two first generation, African American undergraduate students. This was an excellent learning experience for both in terms of developing strategies to address problems that are not well defined as typically found in the classroom. One of these students now plans on not only being 1st in his household with a BS degree, but the first with a PhD.
